utterances.speaker: WATTERS

utterances.speaker: LAWRENCE O'DONNELL, MSNBC HOST
utterances.sentences: The coronavirus crisis is going to get much worse for Donald Trump.

utterances.speaker: UNIDENTIFIED FEMALE
utterances.sentences: Should Americans trust President Trump to deal with this crisis?

utterances.speaker: BLOOMBERG
utterances.sentences: No. He has not prepared for a crisis like this. if (window && window.foxstrike && Array.isArray(window.foxstrike.cmd)) { window.foxstrike.cmd.push(function(Strike) { Strike.insertAd('desktop', 'lb18', 'desktop-desk-ad-lb18', ''); }); } else { console.error('Error: window.foxstrike not found'); }

utterances.speaker: JOE SCARBOROUGH, HOST, MSNBC
utterances.sentences: Our government is woefully ill-unprepared. It seems at least at this early stage.

utterances.speaker: BIDEN
utterances.sentences: No one takes the president's word for this thing. At a minimum, he exaggerates everything. And the idea that he's going to stand there and say everything is fine, don't worry, who's going to believe that?

utterances.speaker: O'DONNELL
utterances.sentences: He will probably stay physically healthy throughout the crisis but his mental health which is weak on his best day can only get much worse.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.sentences: And here's President Trump calling out the spears at the White House earlier today.

utterances.speaker: TRUMP
utterances.sentences: I think that CNN is a very disreputable network. I think they're doing everything they can to instill fear in people and I think it's ridiculous. if (window && window.foxstrike && Array.isArray(window.foxstrike.cmd)) { window.foxstrike.cmd.push(function(Strike) { Strike.insertAd('desktop', 'lb19', 'desktop-desk-ad-lb19', ''); }); } else { console.error('Error: window.foxstrike not found'); } Some of the Democrats are doing it the way it should be, but some of them are trying to gain political favor by saying a lot of untruths. So, some people are giving us credit -- quiet. Some people are giving us credit for that, and some people aren't, but the only ones -- they don't mean it. It's political, it's politics.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.sentences: So, Greg, the president declared a national health emergency, he restricts the travel on China, he brings local and federal health officials together, he organizes a task force. He asks for billions of dollars, he does the quarantines, accelerates the vaccines. What do the Democrats want him to do that he's not doing?

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.sentences: And they're actually not even getting to that place of offering an idea. Like saying here's what I -- they can't even -- because the fact that he did act so fast that he gave the hospital's time to prepare --

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.sentences: Right.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.sentences: -- and that's the most important thing. As you saw this emergency unfold, you saw CNN and you saw the New York Times get their biased mode going. They -- you could see the obvious agenda before your eyes. Then when you pointed out, right, what did they do? They cause -- they accuse you -- if (window && window.foxstrike && Array.isArray(window.foxstrike.cmd)) { window.foxstrike.cmd.push(function(Strike) { Strike.insertAd('desktop', 'lb20', 'desktop-desk-ad-lb20', ''); }); } else { console.error('Error: window.foxstrike not found'); }

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.sentences: Yes.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.sentences: -- of politicizing when you go, Brian Stelter is like secretly saying, you know, this could be it. And then Kaitlan Collins saying let's call it the Trump virus. When you accuse them and show their naked attempts at trying Trump to this they go, you're politicizing this. The -- I mean, I can't use the language that I want to use to describe them.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.sentences: Geraldo will.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.sentences: Geraldo, because you can get away with it.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.sentences: Geraldo, why do you think --

utterances.speaker: RIVERA
utterances.sentences: A gutter feeding punks. if (window && window.foxstrike && Array.isArray(window.foxstrike.cmd)) { window.foxstrike.cmd.push(function(Strike) { Strike.insertAd('desktop', 'lb21', 'desktop-desk-ad-lb21', ''); }); } else { console.error('Error: window.foxstrike not found'); }

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.sentences: That's exactly right. So, as Greg mentioned, you know, they said that the task force was too white.

utterances.speaker: RIVERA
utterances.sentences: What?

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.sentences: They said the travel restrictions were Xenophobic. You know, they said that cut the CD funding -- they never cut any CDC funding. And if you say you guys are politicizing it, they say, no, you're politicizing it. How does that make sense?

utterances.speaker: RIVERA
utterances.sentences: Anyone who exacerbates the fear, the real epidemic of fear, which is the real epidemic, not the virus yet in this country is, like I said, a gutter feeding, you know --

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.sentences: Scumbag.

utterances.speaker: RIVERA
utterances.sentences: -- scumbag.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.sentences: There you go.

utterances.speaker: RIVERA
utterances.sentences: They really are. Scumbag is a good word. Let me -- I want to read you something.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.sentences: Please.

utterances.speaker: RIVERA
utterances.sentences: So, first of all, let me assert my firm belief that the only thing we have to fear is fear itself. Nameless, unreasoning, unjustified terror, which paralyzes needed efforts to convert retreat in advance, 1933, FDR first inaugural address. We have now a politician feeding fear, politicians for their own temporary advantage to cut the president in any way they can, to distinguish themselves from their rivals in this Democratic catfight. They say and do things that have helped tank the stock market. I've lost a fortune this week. Itis very, very disgraceful.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.sentences: But you had a fortune to lose.

utterances.speaker: RIVERA
utterances.sentences: Yes. Sure. But I mean, this is very, very unsettling. And anyone who is exacerbating the unease that the American people feel, shame on them. Reject them. Reject them. They are nothing.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.sentences: Wow.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.sentences: I have to pixelate that.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.sentences: No, we're live.

utterances.speaker: COMPAGNO
utterances.sentences: It's going to be a --

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.sentences: So, you think this would be a time where news organizations would try to tell you the facts, give you the context, and not instill fear, but that's not what we are getting.

utterances.speaker: COMPAGNO
utterances.sentences: No, it's not. And to your point, this is exactly what turns people off about politics, is these guys using a public health crisis or a public health situation to advance their own careers, to further their own team. It's what makes people turn off those news organizations because they need actual facts. I'm not getting my news from there. I'm not getting my actual facts. We're not getting the here's you wash your hands, you take that certain steps, the people at most risk are the infirm and the elderly. The average human will likely get it and won't be affected. I mean, there are things that are important to disseminate, not that I'm the expert but that I'm -- I am responsible for transmitting accurate messaging and information. And to your point about the president, what else do we want our president to do? I would say take executive, decisive action and have a reassuring countenance. Right? Do I want my president running around screaming like, we're all going to die? No. I love that he was like, there's, we are going to be OK. And by the way, I use my authority to take these actions that will ensure that the experts in the public health field in this country will secure that, will execute it accordingly.

utterances.speaker: RIVERA
utterances.sentences: We need a vaccine. That's the only politics that matter right now. We need a vaccine to reassure people. I mean, Japan is going broke, they've got the big Tokyo Olympics coming up.

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.sentences: Yes.

utterances.speaker: RIVERA
utterances.sentences: Eric and I had a Japanese trip planned for spring break.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.sentences: Like out of everything that happened, that might be the most tragic.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.sentences: Yes. Geraldo's travel plans --

utterances.speaker: RIVERA
utterances.sentences: I mean, the travel industry is tanking.

utterances.speaker: COMPAGNO
utterances.sentences: Yes. Eric and I --

utterances.speaker: RIVERA
utterances.sentences: -- people are going to be laid off, people are -- the supply chain of businesses.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.sentences: But you know, pellets on, if you want to work out by yourself, not a bad call right now.

utterances.speaker: RIVERA
utterances.sentences: You're turning your back to me because of fear of contagion or what?

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.sentences: Or maybe -- I haven't spoken yet.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.sentences: No. I'm trying to pivot to Dana to give her chance to speak.

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.sentences: I love the pellets on and I highly recommend it. There is no evidence for the criticism yet.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.sentences: Right.

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.sentences: Right? So, it's obviously nakedly political. The president said that some Democrats have been reasonable and nice and helpful and one of them was Senator Dick Durbin of Illinois.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.sentences: Right.

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.sentences: Two -- the vice president called lots of people, two of them made comments. One of them through Twitter was Governor Inslee of Washington State. Do you remember he ran for president for a while --

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.sentences: Yes.

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.sentences: -- on a climate change thing. He came out on Twitter and said, the vice president called me and I told him, you know, it would be nice if the president cared about science. And it was so wrong. Dick Durbin said I'm so glad the vice president called me. We're all on this together, let's work on it. That's a difference between somebody who is just being political and somebody who is a real true public servant.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.sentences: Just to add, did you see Paul Krugman cheering that the stock market is dropping.

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.sentences: Yes.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.sentences: Because he wants so badly to be proven right. It doesn't matter if everybody's fortunes are suffering, it's because he's right. I have a new -- I have a rule this might be stupid. Do you have -- because I don't look at stocks. Do you have to have the stock ticker up all day, because what that does is it just drives people crazy. You can't -- you know, we know it's bad. Put it away.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.sentences: Yes.

utterances.speaker: RIVERA
utterances.sentences: I think it's an age thing also. The older you get the more obsessed do you --

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.sentences: And Geraldo needs --

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.sentences: I'm still young.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.sentences: Geraldo needs to see how much of his fortune is going. All right. Up next --

utterances.speaker: RIVERA
utterances.sentences: Who knows, it just be my kids.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.sentences: -- what's the most important thing you need to know about the coronavirus? Dr. Marc Siegel is here to tell us next.

utterances.speaker: TRUMP
utterances.sentences: There have been no deaths in the United States at all. A lot of that is attributable to the fact that we close the border very early, otherwise it could be a different story.

utterances.speaker: RIVERA
utterances.sentences: No deaths in the United States as of yet. No deaths. The president reacting of course to the coronavirus, spreading major fears even panic around the planet. Stock markets getting smashed again today as the total number of cases worldwide tops 84,000, almost 3,000 dead. Making matters worse, there are conflicting statements over whether the situation is getting better or worse. The CDC director on the one hand is saying the outbreak may not be inevitable here in this country. The World Health Organization though, warning the epidemic could soon reach every country and every corner of our country. Here to help us sort it all out, Dr. Marc Siegel, our pal. So, welcome. Who is right? The WHO or the CDC? Is it a may not happen here or is it inevitable here?

utterances.speaker: MARC SIEGEL, FOX NEWS MEDICAL CORRESPONDENT
utterances.sentences: First of all, the World Health Organization is a bunch of alarmists and they always overstate the problem, they always make it seem like the world is going to end.

utterances.speaker: RIVERA
utterances.sentences: Who are they? Who is the World Health -- is that --

utterances.speaker: SIEGEL
utterances.sentences: They are part of the United Nations.

utterances.speaker: RIVERA
utterances.sentences: Are they part of the U.N.?

utterances.speaker: SIEGEL
utterances.sentences: Yes. And as a matter of fact, one of their main people who's in charge of communicable diseases was a Chinese health official for over 20 years. So, he has a certain vested interest and there's a lot of power coming out of China influencing the WHO in my opinion, and they haven't really risen up in this situation as they -- they are useful but I think they've been alarmists.

utterances.speaker: RIVERA
utterances.sentences: So, what's the answer to the question?

utterances.speaker: SIEGEL
utterances.sentences: So, the CDC, Geraldo, the CDC hasn't been alarmists until suddenly this week. They announced that it's not a matter of if, but when, and they suddenly got alarmists. Here's the answer --

utterances.speaker: RIVERA
utterances.sentences: Wait, do you think that's why Fauci got taken off the Sunday talk shows?

utterances.speaker: SIEGEL
utterances.sentences: Well, I don't --

utterances.speaker: RIVERA
utterances.sentences: Anthony Fauci who runs the CDC?

utterances.speaker: SIEGEL
utterances.sentences: He's not with the CDC, he's with the NIH.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.sentences: FYI.

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.sentences: ASAP.

utterances.speaker: SIEGEL
utterances.sentences: Geraldo, it was Nancy Messonnier of the CDC who made that comment that it's going to get bad. And here's my answer to your question. And this is what the viewers need to know. We don't know how bad it's going to get, but here's what we do know. The purpose of public health is to contain and to control it. All this frenzy from our side, from the health side, from the doctor's side, from the official side, health official side is to prevent it from getting bad before the genie gets out of the bottle. If we get to a situation where we have embers of a fire here, the fire goes out at the end of the year. Emily, you get to the summer and the fire is out, there's no more virus. But if there's embers, it comes back in the fall. And then it can get worse --

utterances.speaker: RIVERA
utterances.sentences: I think --

utterances.speaker: COMPAGNO
utterances.sentences: Doctor -- sorry.

utterances.speaker: RIVERA
utterances.sentences: This day my wife is crazy trying to get, trying to get sold out on Amazon. I put this on. I put this on, is this to protect me or to protect you from me?

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.sentences: It's your mustache, Geraldo.

utterances.speaker: RIVERA
utterances.sentences: Will you be serious we're getting --

utterances.speaker: GUTGELD
utterances.sentences: No. Facial hair is an issue.

utterances.speaker: RIVERA
utterances.sentences: We have a major crisis --

utterances.speaker: SIEGEL
utterances.sentences: You know what he's hiding in that mustache?

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.sentences: It's worse than coronavirus.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.sentences: No, but it's true.

utterances.speaker: RIVERA
utterances.sentences: Can you answer for us?

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.sentences: It's actually true.

utterances.speaker: RIVERA
utterances.sentences: Is it -- is it to protect you from me or me from you?

utterances.speaker: SIEGEL
utterances.sentences: Your wife is lovely and I want to inform her right now. Here's the answer. The answer is the mask is only useful if you actually have symptoms. If you have a flu or a cold or a coronavirus and you're coughing or sneezing, the mask prevents those droplets from spreading to other people.

utterances.speaker: RIVRA
utterances.sentences: So, it's a public service, a public --

utterances.speaker: SIEGEL
utterances.sentences: Yes.

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.sentences: But only if you are sick.

utterances.speaker: SIEGEL
utterances.sentences: Only if you are sick, if you're not sick --

utterances.speaker: RIVERA
utterances.sentences: Yes?

utterances.speaker: SIEGEL
utterances.sentences: You're spreading a fear message. I've got a mask. I've got to protect myself against. Why? It's not right next to you. It isn't coming down the street.

utterances.speaker: RIVERA
utterances.sentences: Would you wear one?

utterances.speaker: SIEGEL
utterances.sentences: And as a matter of fact, if you don't have -- if you don't have the illness and you've got the mask, do you know what happens? You rub the mask, you put something in your eyes, it collects viruses. That's most useful --

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.sentences: Doctor --

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.sentences: Can I --

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.sentences: Mask, yea or nay?

utterances.speaker: SIEGEL
utterances.sentences: No, if you are not sick. yes, if you're sick.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.sentences: I was just going to ask. One of the things I'm concerned about is when you should go to the E.R. and should you just like -- if you were sick, and I'm not talking about the coronavirus, but if you -- if you break your leg or something -- like what is -- what is -- it's not a good idea to go in the E.R. in the period like this, correct?

utterances.speaker: SIEGEL
utterances.sentences: You go to the E.R. if you need to go to the E.R. but you are leading, Greg, to a really important question that I just learned in Nebraska at the quarantine unit. This coronavirus is characterized by a high fever. So if you have a cough and a shortness of breath and a high fever, this is when you want to go to the E.R. But here's what we need. We need the test kits so that I can in the E.R. find out whether you actually have this coronavirus.

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.sentences: And who's responsible for getting the test kits and why do we not have enough in the United States?

utterances.speaker: SIEGEL
utterances.sentences: Good question. The CDC is responsible for these test kits. They're there. Unfortunately, when they first tried to distribute them, one of the reagents in the kits was off, they had to pull them back. Now they're claiming they're going to be ramping that up over the next couple of weeks. That's the single most important thing because that will also treat the fear, Dana. Somebody comes in, you know, I got a cough, I got a fever. You don't have coronavirus go home.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.sentences: And we just got some numbers. It says that the new cases in China are kind of going down. A couple of weeks ago there was like 1,500, 2,000 new cases per day, and now there's just a couple hundred. Is that a good sign in China? Do they have the right things under control?

utterances.speaker: SIEGEL
utterances.sentences: Well, if you believe that. I don't know how much I believe coming out of China from the beginning to the end. But assuming I believe that, this idea of quarantining a whole region is something out of the Middle Ages. We almost never do it that way. And now they're letting people go back to work there. They could -- they could spread the virus.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.sentences: It could go back again.

utterances.speaker: SIEGEL
utterances.sentences: Yes. So, I'm very dubious.

utterances.speaker: RIVER
utterances.sentences: I think learning of the duplicity of the Chinese is one lesson the epidemic has taught us.

utterances.speaker: COMPAGNO
utterances.sentences: We've heard all day that a dog now has it. What are the implications for viewers of a species jump and can you relate it to something comparable that we know? Should we be afraid by that or do dogs also get common colds and this is something that happens often?

utterances.speaker: SIEGEL
utterances.sentences: You answer your own question. I'm much more concerned about whether it's actually percolating in areas of California or New York and we don't know about it.

utterances.speaker: RIVERA
utterances.sentences: In humans.

utterances.speaker: SIEGEL
utterances.sentences: In humans. When it comes to animals, this coronavirus started in animals. It started in mammals. It's a mammal virus. So it's not surprising that somebody, you know, that is -- the dog is licking them or they're touching them. If human has coronavirus and passes into a dog, that's a weak case.

utterances.speaker: RIVERA
utterances.sentences: That's Greg's dog.

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.sentences: I'm looking at Jesse's face. He's like, oh.

utterances.speaker: SIEGEL
utterances.sentences: Jasper is safe.

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.sentences: Jasper is safe, everybody. Fox News alert.

utterances.speaker: RIVERA
utterances.sentences: It is interesting -- it is interesting that the deaths have hovered around 2,800. They were escalating, spiking up and up and up, then they kind of --

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.sentences: And it's mostly men, right?

utterances.speaker: SIEGEL
utterances.sentences: Well, more men, mostly elderly, mostly with chronic health conditions. And this is what they were treating in Nebraska, by the way, and they got better. Old men with --

utterances.speaker: RIVERA
utterances.sentences: Mustaches?

utterances.speaker: SIEGEL
utterances.sentences: No, no mustaches. If you had pneumonia, they've gotten better. They're actually out of the -- out of the --

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.sentences: This is the most important information.

utterances.speaker: SIEGEL
utterances.sentences: They're getting better. They're getting better.

utterances.speaker: RIVERA
utterances.sentences: Tell us about this stuff. What do you want to -- what do you want to do?

utterances.speaker: SIEGEL
utterances.sentences: Well, no, I wanted to make the point that, of course, disinfecting this table especially is a really good idea. Because I like the idea of this being an alert. There should be an alert for people. It's not coronavirus that's out there, but by the way, don't sneeze and cough on people. If you're sick, wear a mask.

utterances.speaker: RIVERA
utterances.sentences: Don't go to work if you're sick.

utterances.speaker: SIEGEL
utterances.sentences: And don't got to work if you're sick. Not because the coronavirus is there --

utterances.speaker: RIVERA
utterances.sentences: Don't be selfish.

utterances.speaker: SIEGEL
utterances.sentences: Right.

utterances.speaker: RIVERA
utterances.sentences: And generally speaking, when you hear -- generally speaking, when you hear politicians talking about this disease, do you think that they are speaking with, you know, kind of credibility or do you discount just when it comes out of their mouth because they're politicians and just looking for their personal benefit?

utterances.speaker: SIEGEL
utterances.sentences: It depends on who you're talking about. You talked about Tony Fauci at the NIH, I think he's super. He's one of the top infectious disease experts in the country. Redfield at CDC, also a virologist. We have some people on this panel -- on this expert group that was appointed by the President that actually really belonged to be there.

utterances.speaker: RIVERA
utterances.sentences: I really like Mike Bloomberg, but I think what he said about the CDC funding getting cut, and you know, he made some charges that were absolutely untrue. Dr. Marc Siegel --

utterances.speaker: SIEGEL
utterances.sentences: One quick thing. I spoke to Cuccinelli the other day from Homeland Security, he said they have plenty of money left over from Ebola. So now the President is asking for 2.5 billion more. That's good.

utterances.speaker: RIVERA
utterances.sentences: All right. Ebola, guess who Obama picked as the Ebola czar. A guy named Ron Klain. He used to be the chief of staff of Vice President Gore. We pick -- I mean, Trump picks the Vice President, the sitting Vice President Mike Pence. So you get the vice president from Trump, he gets criticized and Obama picks the Chief of Staff of the Vice President. Dr. Siegel, thank you very much. Some breaking news to tell you about President Trump tweeting just moments ago. He is nominating Congressman John Ratcliffe to be Director of National Intelligence. More on that when we get it up next on THE FIVE, the "FASTEST SEVEN."

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.sentences: What?

utterances.speaker: COMPAGNO
utterances.sentences: Welcome back. Time for the "FASTEST SEVEN." First up, Hillary Clinton will likely never have president on her resume, but now she can add podcast host. She is planning to launch a new audio show in late spring just in time for the 2020 election. The format and style of the show will reportedly be influenced by Howard Stern. OK, so Greg, supposedly her lineup will be newsmakers.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.sentences: Right.

utterances.speaker: COMPAGNO
utterances.sentences: If she invited you on, would you say yes?

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.sentences: Of course. You know -- but having a podcast right now it's like saying you have indoor plumbing. Everybody has -- but I have to say, I love this because now we have a treasure trove of her mad tackles to use for sound bites and sound effects on my show, because she like -- it's just going to be we're going to harvest the sound bites every day. Yes.

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.sentences: It'll be interesting to see if she can actually ask questions rather than answer the question as well, right? Like will she -- like one of the great things about Howard Stern is that he asked a question then he -- then he steps back and he lets the interviewer or the interviewee talk. So I don't know. We'll have to see about that.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.sentences: Geraldo doesn't know that.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.sentences: I don't even think her husband is going to listen to this thing. It's going to be a bomb. No one even showed up at her rallies when she was running for president. They had to cancel the tour with her husband and slash ticket prices because she wasn't selling. My mother wouldn't even listen to her.

utterances.speaker: COMPAGNO
utterances.sentences: Oh, my God. Geraldo, would you -- would you listen to it?

utterances.speaker: RIVERA
utterances.sentences: No, not necessarily, but I never liked listening to the person either. I don't know. Howard Stern is great, and he's really evolved as a radio host. It's not about Howard Stern, I know. But he has become one of the best interviewers on the air.

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.sentences: Yes.

utterances.speaker: RIVERA
utterances.sentences: And if Hillary wants the model herself after him, she could -- then she couldn't pick a better role model.

utterances.speaker: COMPAGNO

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD

utterances.utterance: Because it's going to be like, you know what, just give me, going to have Trump for another four years, we can deal with it in 2024. Life goes pretty fast.
